issues.description: The problem statement and template use an interface named 'Milkable' (with method messageOnMilk()), but the solution repository introduces an interface named 'Dairy' with messageOnMilk() and has classes (Goat, Seal) implement 'Dairy'. Meanwhile, solution's Milkable.java file is empty. This creates a type/name mismatch: students following the UML or template will implement/use 'Milkable', but the solution reference uses 'Dairy' (and leaves Milkable empty). This inconsistency will confuse students and prevents direct comparison between student code and the provided solution (and will cause compile errors if template Main expects Milkable while solution classes implement Dairy).
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the interface name and usage across artifacts. Replace the 'Dairy' interface in the solution with the expected 'Milkable' interface (or rename it to Milkable) and ensure Milkable.java declares String messageOnMilk();. Update Goat and Seal to implement Milkable (not Dairy), and remove or repurpose any empty Milkable.java stub so the solution matches the problem statement and template. This preserves the intended pedagogy while restoring structural consistency.

issues.description: The problem statement and template refer to an interface named 'Milkable' (the UML and tasks explicitly use the name Milkable, and Main.java's example uses a Milkable[]). The solution implementation instead provides an interface named 'Dairy' and has Goat and Seal implement Dairy. This is a direct identifier mismatch for the same conceptual entity (the interface providing messageOnMilk()). Students reading the problem/template will look for/implement 'Milkable' but the reference solution uses 'Dairy', causing confusion mapping the requirement to the solution and making it unclear which interface name is canonical.
issues.suggested_fix:
Unify the interface name across artifacts. Preferred fixes (pick one):
1) Rename the solution interface 'Dairy' to 'Milkable' (file Dairy.java -> Milkable.java) and update Goat.java and Seal.java to implement 'Milkable' instead of 'Dairy'.
OR
2) Add a Milkable.java interface in the solution that declares messageOnMilk() and make it the interface used by Goat and Seal (or make Milkable extend Dairy) so the solution matches the problem/template naming. This preserves the intended API and removes student mapping confusion.
